user_request: A Mother's Day poem about how a mother's love is unconditional.
final_poem:
# Unconditional

At six-thirteen in the morning, your name
left my lips the way it always does—
no precondition, no particular urgency,
just the ordinary habit of a heart
that has forgotten it is practice-making.

You were not born into that sentence.
No contract was ever signed.

I loved you before I could say it,
the way a dog knows snow means certain things without being taught.

All those years—you in your high chair
cruising left on repetition, laughing
at the red truck we'd seen once—
my love for you did not require me to name it.

It sat with its backpack full of quiet
in the back of every room,
sturdier than my vows, loyaler
than any promise I could make because
promise is a thing I have to do.
Love just does what loves do—

it stays.

Even when I was afraid for things
I didn't understand—vaccines,
the word *stranger* separated from safety by only one syllable—
even then, your posture was enough.
The way the dog knows, the way a building holds its shape through earthquakes:
nothing shakes it into not-being.

Now you're thirteen and you roll your eyes
at whatever I'm reading. You'd rather
be outside. Fair enough.

But somewhere in that irreverence,
somewhere beneath the sassed dispatch,
there's still a girl who wakes at dark
and invents mothers in the attic
because love so vast has no other place to live but fiction—
and fiction is permitted.

I could not give you unconditional.
That phrase is for God, or for rent,
something due on a certain day.
But I can tell you what happens:
every morning. Every not-yet-sunlight hour
when sleep still has its own country.
I am there before the word for love arrives,
shaking it out like a wet towel—
*here,* I'll say, *here is more.*
And you will take it or set me right.

Because that's how it works with mothers:
the goods arrive early. Always
in the excess packaging of extra breaths,
anatomical surpluses, the way the body
learns to make milk before it knows
what child might use it.

Unconditional doesn't mean I stop
correcting your grammar or loading the dishwasher.
It means I keep doing those things
the way a spouse keeps showing up at dinner—
not out of duty but because the table is set,
because someone has to sit there,
and nobody else volunteers.

This is not a feeling with legs.
It lives in actions. The small, unavoidable ones:
laundry on Tuesday, doctor's appointments,
singing *you're special* into your pillow at sleepovers
even though you are already standing
in the fullness of whatever you will be,

which has nothing to do with me
and everything to do with being.

I could not give you that.
But I can keep trying—not because it's earned,
not because I'm practicing a skill,
but because some days you need someone
at the gate, just past the property line,
holding open what amounts to little more than a fence,

and that is still enough. That is still
the whole definition of being
unconditional.
